cards.back: The SI unit for the amount of substance, representing $6.022 \times 10^{23}$ particles.
The number of particles in one mole of a substance: $6.022 \times 10^{23}$.
The mass of one mole of a pure substance, usually expressed in g/mol.

cards.front: How do you calculate **molar mass** of a compound?
cards.back: Sum the atomic masses of all atoms present in the chemical formula.

cards.front: What is the formula to convert **mass to moles**?
cards.back: $\text{Moles} = \frac{\text{Mass (g)}}{\text{Molar Mass (g/mol)}}$

cards.front: What is the formula to convert **moles to particles**?
cards.back: $\text{Particles} = \text{Moles} \times (6.022 \times 10^{23})$

cards.front: What is **Molar Volume** of a gas at STP?
cards.back: One mole of any gas occupies **22.4 L** at Standard Temperature and Pressure.
Standard Temperature and Pressure: 0Â°C (273.15 K) and 1 atm (101.3 kPa).
The percentage by mass of each element in a compound.
The simplest whole-number ratio of atoms of each element in a compound.
The actual number of atoms of each element in a molecule; a multiple of the empirical formula.
The study of quantitative relationships between reactants and products in a chemical reaction.
A conversion factor that relates the amounts in moles of any two substances in a chemical reaction, derived from coefficients.
The reactant that is completely consumed first in a reaction, limiting the amount of product formed.
The substance that is not used up completely in a reaction.
The maximum amount of product that can be produced from a given amount of reactant (calculated).
The measured amount of product physically obtained from a reaction in a lab.

cards.front: What is the formula for **percent yield**?
cards.back: $\text{Percent Yield} = \left( \frac{\text{Actual Yield}}{\text{Theoretical Yield}} \right) \times 100\%$
A measure of concentration defined as the number of moles of solute per liter of solution.
